title: AFC Wimbledon 2 MK Dons 0: Phoenix club beat bitter rivals in first ever London meeting

text:
AFC Wimbledon 2 MK Dons 0: Phoenix club beat bitter rivals in first ever London meeting 
Lyle Taylor and Jake Reeves on target in front of fanatical support By Ben Hunt 14th March 2017, 10:11 pm Updated: 14th March 2017, 11:54 pm Comments AFC WIMBLEDON beat bitter rivals Milton Keynes at home in front of a raucous crowd at Kingsmeadow. 
Second-half goals from Jake Reeves and Lyle Taylor blew the roof off the stadium to send the home side into raptures. Reuters Wimbledon players celebrate after the 2-0 win over bitter rivals Milton Keynes Rex Features 7 It was the first time the game had been played in London since the club was franchised 
Since being formed in 2002, when the Football Association controversially allowed the franchise of Wimbledon FC to Milton Keynes, the south London side had never hosted this explosive fixture. 
Police number were boosted from the usual 20 to around 150 for the grudge match with the game receiving the highest-priority billing by the Met. 
Keep up to date with ALL the EFL news, gossip, transfers and goals plus fixtures, results and live match commentary 
Visiting fans were only allowed in if they had made the journey south on the official supporters’ coaches. 
And even then they were forced to walk the last 500 yards under a heavy police presence to avoid coming into contact with the home fans. 
Despite the safety warnings, MK Dons chairman Pete Winkelman, who masterminded the move from Wimbledon to Milton Keynes, did attend the game. Reuters The home side refused to put MK’s name or club badge on the programme MOST READ IN SPORT Marcos Rojo deserves five-game ban for STAMP on Eden Hazard... just like Tyrone Mings Red Mist Marcos Rojo facing retrospective FA ban after appearing to stamp on Chelsea's Eden Hazard during FA Cup clash at Stamford Bridge CAN'T KEEP CALM AND CARRA ON Hilarious moment Jamie Carragher snaps at Jamie Redknapp for interrupting his expert analysis on Sky Sports end of an era Arsene Wenger's right hand man Boro Primorac to quit Arsenal after 20 years for Turkish side Konyaspor Red rage Jose Mourinho angrily kicked ball towards Antonio Conte after Ander Herrera was sent off as bitter feud between pair continues at Stamford Bridge HIT THE ROAD Jack Wilshere facing more rejection with Bournemouth losing interest in making loan from Arsenal permanent 
Winkelman has been the focal point for much of the Wimbledon backlash but he stood with the visiting end after shunning AFC Wimbledon’s offer of hospitality. 
With so much bitterness between the two sides, it translated into a cracking atmosphere prior to kick off. 
And the home side certainly made the better start with Tom Elliott and Taylor having chances to break the deadlock. 
Defender Paul Robinson also saw his header saved by David Martin as they continued to press for an opener. Reuters Jake Reeves celebrates after the second goal at Kingsmeadow Reuters 7 The Met police gave the game top priority – with 150 officers compared to the usual 20 
But as they failed to make the most of their chances, Milton Keynes started to find a foot in the game. 
And Harvey Barnes’ shot forced an excellent save from AFC Wimbledon keeper James Shea to keep the scores level. 
After the restart, Taylor’s cross-cum-shot almost squeezed in at the near post, forcing Martin to make a smart save. Jon Meads then shot wide from the resulting corner. Reuters Wimbledon didn’t put ‘Dons’ on the scoreboard 
Milton Keynes eventually crumbled under the pressure when Reeves first the Dons ahead on 61 minutes. 
Taylor’s cross from the right was headed back across goal by Andy Bircham and Reeves slammed home through a crowd of players. 
Taylor doubled the Dons’ lead nine minutes later when he latched on to kick thrown and raced forward before firing a low shot past Martin. 
The two goal deficit prompted the best spell from Milton Keynes as Kieran Agard and Ed Upson both drew saves from Shea. Reuters 7 The home fans created an electric atmosphere at Kingsmeadow 
But it was the Dons who looked likeliest to add to their tally as Dean Parrett teed up Elliott but the powerful forward could not direct his header at goal. 
Wimbledon boss Neal Ardley, who has already seen his side win at Stadium MK in the Johnstone’s Paint Trophy, led his players on a lap of honour at full-time on a famous night for the Dons. 
Ardley said: “It means a lot to me because you want to be taken in by the fans and you don’t want to be just be judged on one game, but you know that one game makes a big difference. 
“So hopefully there will be a few hugs towards me after this!” Rival boss Robbie Neilson added: “I am disappointed. There was a lot of build up for the game and everyone has been talking about it for a long time. 
“We had the better chances in the first half, but they came out and scored the first goal and it turned the game.” Goals of the Week : Watch the finest Premier League strikes from the Weekend’s fixtures
